{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3532761,"name":"asaf meizner","username":"Asaf","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asaf/{size}/210024_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T14:34:57.039Z","cooked":"

We are using 12v adressable LEDs with di connected to the roborio and 12v and ground connected to the small connectors on the PDH.

20250219_1337291920×3410 378 KB

We are incountering an issue that only on the robot the colors are reversed (when we put in red it gives green ect…) but when simulating the code in the sim the colors are correct.

Also when running effects on the robot the led are jittery when changing color (as seen in the video bellow) which doesnt happen in the simulation.

Does anyone know why this is happening? We assume its an electrical issue due to it working in the sim but not entirely sure.

Couple things -

  1. Add ground between the Rio and the lights. So DI and GND from Rio to lights, 12+ and gnd from lights to power supply.
  2. Make sure your code matches the lights. WPILIB works off of RGB. The lights from Andymark are GRB. Could throw off the color. Other brands of lights may have other color order in the code.
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T14:49:52.147Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":65,"readers_count":64,"score":63.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":492303,"topic_slug":"led-jitter-issues-only-on-robot","display_username":"Justin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32000,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Resident LED and CAN advocate"},"post_url":"/t/led-jitter-issues-only-on-robot/492303/2","custom_user_title":"Resident LED and CAN advocate","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3532796,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T14:50:12.945Z","cooked":"

The wrong colors is set by your strip having a different R G B order in the data.

Look at the setColorOrder function and call it with the order matching your strip (via trial and error, perhaps).

The jitter could be something else, but the color order is a common pitfall.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T14:50:12.945Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":63,"readers_count":62,"score":17.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492303,"topic_slug":"led-jitter-issues-only-on-robot","display_username":"Jim Sokoloff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/AddressableLED.html#setColorOrder(edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.AddressableLED.ColorOrder)","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"AddressableLED (WPILib API 2025.3.1)","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66298,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"97 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/led-jitter-issues-only-on-robot/492303/3","custom_user_title":"97 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3532797,"name":"Vince Kaufhold","username":"VinceBuilds","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vincebuilds/{size}/231918_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T14:50:42.872Z","cooked":"

Also worth noting a lot of 12V led’s require 2 data lines to control them. I see the open pad on the strip so that might need a connection to the rio as well.

True with a caveat - DI is the main data line, BI is the backup. This allows down stream LEDs to operate if one LED fails, however a 3 conductor setup still works when using DI.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-19T14:52:33.204Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":57,"readers_count":56,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492303,"topic_slug":"led-jitter-issues-only-on-robot","display_username":"Justin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":67678,"username":"VinceBuilds","name":"Vince Kaufhold","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/vincebuilds/{size}/231918_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32000,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Resident LED and CAN advocate"},"post_url":"/t/led-jitter-issues-only-on-robot/492303/5","custom_user_title":"Resident LED and CAN advocate","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3532910,"name":"evanperryg","username":"evanperryg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/evanperryg/{size}/259696_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-19T15:59:03.770Z","cooked":"

I’ll second all the advice folks have given so far, especially the thing about a ground line to the RIO. IME writing firmware-level drivers for these WS2812-derived LEDs, they can be pretty finicky about their signal and ground paths, especially in longer strips.

Some other advice:

1. RGBW

Make sure you didn’t buy the RGBW strips. A glance at WPI’s docs suggests that those don’t work with their library at all.

2. Signal path resistor

The datasheet says nothing about the matter, but I’ve seen many driver circuits with a 220Ω resistor in series with the signal line. 1732 does this. Many of Adafruit’s Neopixel boards do it too (example). But, 1732 and Adafruit are both connecting to an Arduino, not a RIO, so YMMV.

Consensus online seems to be that the resistor isn’t there to help the LEDs, but to protect the microcontroller/RIO. Again, YMMV. If you don’t have 220Ω resistors laying around, try out a 120Ω CAN terminating resistor.

3. Power

This one isn’t relevant to your case - it’s more of a general PSA for anyone else reading this. Never, ever attempt to power LED strips directly off the RIO. You will have a bad time. Your RIO will have a worse time.

Look at the setColorOrder function and call it with the order matching your strip (via trial and error, perhaps).

FYI, this function is new and only available in WPILib 2025.3.1

thoughts/experiences","slug":"pdp-2-0-what-are-your-thoughts-experiences","posts_count":10,"reply_count":6,"highest_post_number":10,"image_url":null,"created_at":"2025-05-20T23:49:26.122Z","last_posted_at":"2025-05-21T05:58:10.486Z","bumped":true,"bumped_at":"2025-05-21T05:58:10.486Z","archetype":"regular","unseen":false,"pinned":false,"unpinned":null,"excerpt":"I’m curious to know the experiences that teams had using the PDP 2.0.
